title: Levinas Ethics
description: Comprehensive review of Emmanuel Levinas, Ethics of Care, and Phenomenology of the Other

flashcards.front: Who is the philosopher associated with 'Ethics as First Philosophy'?
flashcards.back: Emmanuel Levinas

flashcards.front: What is 'Theodicy'?
flashcards.back: The attempt to justify God's goodness despite the existence of evil (often implying suffering has a divine purpose).

flashcards.front: Why did Levinas reject Theodicy?
flashcards.back: After the Holocaust, he believed nothing can justify the suffering of others; it is useless and we must simply respond with compassion.

flashcards.front: What is 'The Sameness of Things' in Levinas' critique?
flashcards.back: The tendency of Western philosophy to group all people under one label ('Beings'), erasing their individual differences.

flashcards.front: What concept refers to the unique identity of a person that cannot be 'totalized'?
flashcards.back: The Singularity of Things

flashcards.front: According to Levinas, where do we encounter traces of the 'Infinite Good'?
flashcards.back: In the Face of the Other.

flashcards.front: What is the primary command or 'First Word' of the Face?
flashcards.back: "Thou Shalt Not Kill"

flashcards.front: How does Levinas describe the status of the Other relative to the Self?
flashcards.back: The Other is Superior (possessing Highness, Holiness, and Divinity).

flashcards.front: Does Levinas believe responsibility is a choice?
flashcards.back: No. Responsibility is 'incumbent' on us; the mere presence of the Other makes us responsible.

flashcards.front: What is the 'Ethics of Care'?
flashcards.back: A normative ethical theory emphasizing relationships, responsiveness, and context over universal rules.

flashcards.front: Why is the Ethics of Care sometimes called 'feminine morality'?
flashcards.back: It is associated with natural impulses of compassion and caregiving historically linked to women/child-bearing.

flashcards.front: How does the Ethics of Care differ from Utilitarianism?
flashcards.back: It refuses to sacrifice one person for the good of the group; it seeks to maximize everyone's needs through relationship.

flashcards.front: How did Hegel view the 'Other'?
flashcards.back: As a counter-entity or object needed to define the Self.

flashcards.front: How did Husserl view the 'Other'?
flashcards.back: As an 'Alter-Ego' (another version of the Self), known through Intersubjectivity.

flashcards.front: What term does Levinas use to criticize Western philosophy's tendency to reduce the Other to the Self?
flashcards.back: Totalization (or Egology).

flashcards.front: What is the 'Welcome Approach'?
flashcards.back: Levinas' alternative to totalization: treating the Other as a stranger to be welcomed, not analyzed.

flashcards.front: Which modern personality exemplifies Levinas' ethics by supporting coffee farmers in Africa?
flashcards.back: Hugh Jackman

flashcards.front: Which quote from Dostoyevsky does Levinas often cite regarding responsibility?
flashcards.back: "We are all responsible for everyone and everything, and I am more than all others."

flashcards.front: What is 'Peacemaking Justice'?
flashcards.back: An ancient approach to justice involving compassion, connectedness, and mindfulness.

flashcards.front: According to Levinas, does the search for God end in heaven?
flashcards.back: No, it ends at the face of the neighbor.
